question:
(a) What class of manure do each of specimens A (POULTRY DROPPINGS) and B (N-P-K 15-15-15) belong to? [2 marks]

(b) List three characteristics of each of specimens A and B. [6 marks]

(c) List two precautions to be observed when applying each of specimens A and B. [4 marks]

(d) State which of the specimens is recommended to improve clay soil. Give two reasons for your answer. (3 marks]
answer:
(a) Class of Manure:

  • Specimen A; -Organic manure
  • Specimen B - Inorganic manure

b) Characteristics of; 

specimen A (Poultry droppings)

  • it is bulky .
  • Rick in micro-organisms .
  • Contains many plant nutrients/improves soil fertility
  • The nutrient concentrations are fairly low
  • Capable of binding soil particles together / improves soil structure
  • Has a bad smell Improves soil temperature
  • It is structureless/amorphous
  • Tends to be neutral in reaction
  • Low availability of nutrients
  • Nutrients not easily leached/lasts longer in the soil Reduces soil erosion by improving soil structure
  • Variable nutrient concentration

Specimen B (N-P-K 5-15);

  • Granular in structure
  • Has pungent smell
  • Contains only few mineral nutrients
  • The concentrations of these nutrients are high
  • The nutrients are fixed in definite proportion
  • Not bulky in nature
  • Easily leached; does not last long in the soil
  • Does not reduce soil erosion
  • Nutrients are readily available
  • Hygroscopic

(c) Precautions to take when applying:

Specimen A (poultry droppings) -

  • Should not be applied when fresh to crops on the field
  • Must not be allowed to touch the plants
  • Should cure properly before application/fully decomposed before applying
  • Wash hands immediately after application
  • Wear protective clothing
  • Should be applied when soil is wet

Specimen B (N-P-K 15-15-15) -

  • Do not allow direct contact with the plant
  • Do not apply when the soil is very dry
  • When applying manually always wear gloves
  • Wash hands immediately after application
  • Do not apply to alkaline soils
  • Do not eat, drink or smoke when applying the fertilizers
  • Remove all ornamentals from the body
  • Do soil test to know deficient nutrients before applying

(d) Specimen recommended to improve clay soil is - Specimen A (Poultry droppings)

Reasons:

  • It binds clayey particles together thus opening up / enlarging the pores
  • lt improves water percolation
  • lt improves aeration
  • It improves soil fertility
  • It improves oil drainage
  • lt will improve soil temperature in clay soils
  • It will enhance the release of locked nutrients and make them more available.

question:
The diagrams below represent two modern equipment used in commercial animal production. Use them to answer question (a), (b) and (c).

            

(a) ldentify the equipment labelled C and D. {2 marks}

(b) Name the parts labelled I to VIl in diagrams C and D. {7 marks}

(c) State three precautions to be observed when using each of the two equipment {6 marks}
answer:
(a) ldentification of equipment labelled;

  • C- Incubator,
  • D- Milking machine

(b) Labelling of Parts of the two equipment;

  • I - Thermometer
  • II - Egg
  • Ill - Egg tray
  • IV - Water
  • V - Source of heat
  • VI - Teat cup
  • VII. Source of power/Generator/Vacuum pump

(C) Precautions to be observed when using;

C: Incubator -

  • Only fertile eggs should be set and retained in the incubator
  • Eggs must be clean
  • No washing of eggs with water (because this tends to Increase the porous nature of the egg thereby increasing the respiration of the embryo)
  • Eggs must be fresh; that is, they should not be stored for more than two weeks prior to their journey to the incubator.
  • Eggs must be disinfested at least three to four (3-4) hours before arranging them in the incubator
  • Arrange eggs such that the air space end is up
  • Uniformly sized eggs should be set
  • Monitor the temperature inside the incubator
  • Ensure adequate exchange of gases in the incubator
  • Set the incubator away from the walls for proper ventilation
  • The Relative Humidity must be constantly monitored.

B: Milking Machine -

  • The udder should be cleaned thoroughly before milking
  • The foremilk should be tested with test cup
  • The milker should concentrate when milking
  • The dairy animal should be treated with care, that is, handled gently; i.e. apply little pressure to the udder.
  • The handlers should not be distracted in any form like smoking or drinking while milking.
  • Use slightly warm water to wash/scrub the udder/teats
  • Avoid any form of noise during milking
  • Introduce some feed to the milking animal
  • Supply light, gentle music to further induce the animal to let down milk.

question:
(a) Identify specimens E, F. G and H. {2 marks}

Specimen E,              Specimen F;                    Specimen G;                      Specimen H;

                                 

(b) Name the part of the plant usually attacked by each of specimens E, F, G, and H. {2 marks}

(c) Give two ways by which each of the specimens damages crops. {8 marks}

(d) State three methods of controlling specimen E. {3 marks}
answer:
a) ldentification of specimens:

  • E - Maize weevil
  • F - Cotton Stainer bug/Dysdercus
  • G - Termite
  • H - Grasshopper

(b) Part of Plant attacked by specimens

  • E - Maize grains
  • F - Cotton bolls/okro fruits/akee apple
  • G - Crop stems/roots/grains of lodged cereals
  • H - Plant leaves and young shoots

(c) Damages caused to crops;

Specimen E (Maize Weevil);

  • Bores into the grains of maize and creates holes
  • Destroys the embryo and hence prevents germination
  • Eats the endosperm and reduces food value
  • Vents serve as sites for secondary infections

Specimen F (Dysdercus/cotton stainer bug);

  • Pierces into mature cotton bolls/okro fruit/akee apple
  • Stains the cotton lint
  • Vents created serve as sites for secondary infection
  • Prevents good fruit formation in okro
  • Causes premature drop of fruits

Specimen G (Termite);

  • Chews the stem and roots of plants and tubers
  • Weakens the stem and roots of plants and make them to lodge
  • Destroys seed grains lying on the field
  • Also creates tunnels for secondary infection

Specimen H (Grasshopper) ;

  • Causes defoliation of crops
  • Young shoots are destroyed
  • Wounds left on the crops can serve as vents for secondary infection
  • Buds are also destroyed
  • Reduces the photosynthetic ability of crop plants
  • Reduces the growth of crop plants

(d) Methods of Controlling specimen E (Maize Weevil);

  • Dry grains very well before storing
  • Harvest early soon after drying
  • Store grains in air-tight containers/hermetic storage
  • Apply pesticides to the grains before storage
  • Fumigate storage facilities
  • Use smoke to kill or ward off the weevils
  • Store grains in hot dried pepper/neem extracts

question:
(a) ldentify specimens l, J, and K.

Specimen I:                    Specimen J;                 Specimen K;

                            

(b) State three functions of each of specimens I, J and K to the animal.

(c) Name the process marks in preserving fresh quantity of specimen L 

(d) Give five products that can be produced from specimen L (MILK).
answer:
(a) ldentification of Specimens

  • Specimen I - Piece of liver
  • J - Piece of ruminant skin
  • K - Piece of rumen/part of ruminant

(b) Functions of Specimens:

I (Liver) -

  • Manufactures blood proteins
  • Stores vitamins
  • Secretes bile
  • Detoxifies poisonous substances
  • Destroys old red blood cells
  • Metabolizes nutrients - carbohydrates, proteins, etc./ deamination of amino acids
  • Stores iron Storage of glycogen/regulation of blood sugar / excess carbohydrate
  • Also stores large quantity of blood  
  • Regulates body temperature through metabolism of nutrient
  • Storage of iron
  • Synthesis of enzymes

J (Skin);

  • Prevention of entry into body of dangerous substances
  • Mechanical protection of the body
  • Protection of body from irradiation sun rays
  • Involved in the thermoregulation
  • Enables animals to have sensation of touch, pain, heat or cold/response to stimuli
  • Secretes oil that lubricates the skin
  • Vitamin Ds synthesis with the aid of sunlight
  • Storage of excess fat
  • Promotion of milk since the udder is modified skin
  • Secretion of sweat / excretion

K(Rumen);

  • Mechanical breakdown of coarse fibrous feeds into smaller particles
  • Involved in the digestion of fibrous feed by
  • Vitamin B synthesis
  • Absorption of Volatile Fatty Acids
  • Fermentation of carbohydrate substances into simpler Compounds
  • Storage of hurriedly ingested feed for further digestion later (rumination)
  • Low-quality proteins are converted to higher quality proteins inside the rumen
  • Propulsion of ingested feed into other stomach compartments
  • Harbours millions of microbes which are fibre digestion.

(c) Process of Preserving specimen L (Milk); Pasteurization

(d) Products that can be produced from specimen L (Milk) 

  • Whey
  • Cheese
  • lce cream
  • Casein
  • Condensed/Canned milk
  • Curd
  • Butter scotch
  • Butter from milk fat
  • Dried milk powder
  • Yoghurt
